term.definition: The set of activities that are associated with making decisions in groups, or other forms of power relations among individuals.
A coordinated group action focused on a political, social, or religious issue or ideology.
The movement to end slavery.
A widely held cultural belief in the 19th-century United States that American settlers were destined to expand across North America.
The political policy of promoting or protecting the interests of native or indigenous inhabitants over those of immigrants, including the support of immigration-restriction measures.
An individual authorized to interact with American Indian tribes on behalf of the government.
Authorized the president to negotiate with southern Indigenous tribes for their removal to federal territory west of the Mississippi River in exchange for white settlement of their ancestral lands.

Treaty granted 2.24 million acres of land to the United States in exchange for establishment of three reservations, cash payments over a period of twenty years, and recognition of traditional native fishing and hunting rights.
Land reserved through the Indian Removal Act of 1830 which was earmarked for the Native Americans and guaranteed the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the natives and their property.
A treaty between the United Kingdom and the United States that was signed on June 15, 1846, in Washington, D.C. and which brought an end to the Oregon boundary dispute
Mass immigration of settlers to the area surrounding Fraser Canyon in British Columbia
The movement of people between distant geographical locations.
A particular mode of travel between locations
A defined path of transportation with improved surfaces for use by vehicles
Railroad, mode of land transportation in which flange-wheeled vehicles move over two parallel steel rails, or tracks,
A large watercraft that travels the world's oceans and other sufficiently deep waterways, carrying goods or passengers, or in support of specialized missions, such as defense, research, and fishing.
A symbolic depiction emphasizing relationships between elements of some space, such as objects, regions, or themes.
Tools or other objects necessary to complete a job or objective
A class of heavy military ranged weapons built to launch munitions far beyond the range and power of infantry firearms.
A group of long buildings built to house military personnel or laborers.
A set of expectations that are required by any governing entity including the self, groups, classes, fields, industries, or societies.
An armed conflict between the American colonies and Great Britain, secured a United States of America independent from Great Britain.
An armed conflict between the United States and Mexico from 1846 to 1848 following the 1845 U.S. annexation of Texas
A military society founded in 1847 by United States Army officers of the Mexican–American War.
A major Union operation launched in southeastern Virginia from March through July 1862, the first large-scale offensive in the Eastern Theater.
A largely bloodless border confrontation between the United States and the British Colony of Vancouver Island

An armed conflict that took place in the Puget Sound area of the state of Washington in 1855–56, between the United States military, local militias and members of the Indigenous tribes of the Nisqually, Muckleshoot, Puyallup, and Klickitat.
A conflict from 1835 to 1842 in Florida between the United States and Indigenous groups collectively known as Seminoles.
A massacre of nearly three hundred Lakota people by soldiers of the United States Army.

A United States service academy in West Point, New York. Originally established as a fort, it is the oldest of the five American service academies and educates cadets for commissioning into the United States Army.
The structuring of the armed forces

A social-cultural system of designated behaviors and practices, morals, beliefs, worldviews, texts, sanctified places, prophecies, ethics, or organizations, that generally relates humanity to supernatural, transcendental, and spiritual elements.
An Abrahamic monotheistic religion based on the life and teachings of Jesus of Nazareth.

Core beliefs of Catholicism are found in the Nicene Creed. The Catholic Church teaches that it is the one, holy, catholic and apostolic church founded by Jesus Christ in his Great Commission, that its bishops are the successors of Christ's apostles, and that the pope is the successor to Saint Peter, upon whom primacy was conferred by Jesus Christ.
The office of the ministers of religion, who have been commissioned ("ordained") with the Holy orders of the Catholic Church
A person sent on a religious mission, especially one sent to promote Christianity in a foreign country.
A form of Christianity that originated with the 16th-century Reformation,[a] a movement against, what its followers perceived to be, errors in the Catholic Church.

The Episcopal Church, based in the United States with additional dioceses elsewhere, is a member church of the worldwide Anglican Communion. It is a mainline Protestant denomination and is divided into nine provinces
The oldest and largest Methodist denomination in the United States from its founding in 1784 until 1939. It was also the first religious denomination in the US to organize itself on a national basis.
An infection of the small intestine spread mostly by unsafe water and unsafe food that has been contaminated with human feces containing the bacteria.
A type of gastroenteritis most commonly caused by contamination of food and water with feces due to poor sanitation.
The science and practice of caring for a patient, managing the diagnosis, prognosis, prevention, treatment, palliation of their injury or disease, and promoting their health.
A highly contagious infectious disease spread through the coughs and sneezes of infected people.
A disease resulting from a lack of vitamin C.
An infectious disease characterized by lesions on the skin.
The maintenance or improvement of health via the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, amelioration, or cure of disease, illness, injury, and other physical and mental impairments in people.
Winter holiday in the Christian faith
Washing, ironing, and mending of clothes or other textiles
Standards and style of clothing
A form of activity that holds the attention and interest of an audience or gives pleasure and delight.
Activities that benefit society such as voting, or volunteering
A collaborative form of performing art
Recreational activity allowing young people to interact in a socially acceptable setting
A periodical publication containing written information about current events
Weekly publication from 1855-1857
Daily newspaper serving the Vancouver, Washington, and Clark County, Washington area; first published as a weekly on October 10, 1890
Non-partisan newspaper first published in March of 1858
An early women's magazine, was first published in 1828 in Boston, Massachusetts.
American women's magazine that was published in Philadelphia from 1830 to 1878. It was the most widely circulated magazine in the period before the Civil War.[
Everyday lives and experiences of children
Formal education of children and young adults
The construction and assigned usage of houses or buildings collectively, for the purpose of sheltering people.
Production of woven products
The making of quilts
Groups of people meeting regularly to sew together
An activity of leisure, leisure being discretionary time.
A winter pastime typically consisting of lying or sitting in a sleigh or sled and sliding down a hill of snow.
One of the first military fortifications built by the U.S. north of the Columbia River in what was to become the State of Washington.

Established in 1983, with the purpose of restoring and preserving historic Fort Steilacoom in order to perpetuate the significance of the site for the benefit of the public by operating a museum complex and a strong educational program stressing the role of the Fort in Northwest history.
Protection and care of cultural property including artworks, architecture, archaeology, and museum collections.
Planned activities whose purpose is to promote services meant to inform the wider community about heritage assets and the need to utilise them.
100 year anniversary
The act of restoring something to its original state; may refer to: Conservation and restoration of cultural heritage

Founded by the U.S. Army in 1849 near Lake Steilacoom, among the first military fortifications built by the U.S. north of the Columbia River in what was to become the State of Washington, the fort was constructed due to civilian agitation about the massacre in 1847 at the Whitman (Waiilatpu) mission.
A 2,170-mile (3,490 km) east–west, large-wheeled wagon route and emigrant trail in the United States that connected the Missouri River to valleys in Oregon.

Organized incorporated territory of the United States that existed from August 14, 1848, until February 14, 1859, when the southwestern portion of the territory was admitted to the Union as the State of Oregon.

A 19th-century territorial dispute over the political division of the Pacific Northwest of North America between several nations that had competing territorial and commercial aspirations in the region.
Organized incorporated territory of the United States that existed from March 2, 1853, until November 11, 1889, when the territory was admitted to the Union as the State of Washington.
Persons who have migrated to an area and established a permanent residence there, often to colonize the area.
The social science that studies the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.
The exchange of goods and services, especially on a large scale.
A sustained, long-term downturn in economic activity in one or more economies
A particular form or branch of economic or commercial activity.
Railroad, mode of land transportation in which flange-wheeled vehicles move over two parallel steel rails, or tracks,
The process of hunting of whales for their usable products
A skilled worker that specializes in a particular trade (occupation or field of work).
An alternative nickname for the 'Forty-Niners', the desperate poor from Europe who arrived to try to make their fortunes out of gold on the west coast of America in 1849.
The use of scientific principles to design and build machines, structures, and other items, including bridges, tunnels, roads, vehicles, and buildings.
A military construction or building designed for the defense of territories in warfare, and is also used to establish rule in a region during peacetime.
An important fur trading and farming post of the Hudson's Bay Company in the Puget Sound area, part of the Hudson's Bay Company's Columbia Department.
A 19th-century fur trading post that was the headquarters of the Hudson's Bay Company's Columbia Department, located in the Pacific Northwest.
A United States Army fort located in Walla Walla, Washington.
A United States Army installation in the southwestern corner of the New York City borough of Brooklyn, the original fort was completed in 1831

Attempt by two missionary couples, Whitmans and Spaldings, to evangalize indigenous populations of the Pacific Northwest ending with the deaths of the Whitmans and 11 others at the hands of the Cayuse peoples, prompting Congress to declare Oregon a U.S. territory and precipitating the Cayuse war.
Orginial farming settlement on the future site of Fort Steilacoom
A lake located in Lakewood in Pierce County, Washington, United States.
Originally inhabited by the Puyallup people, the first white settlers in the region were part of the first wagon train to cross the Cascade Range at Naches Pass in 1853.
A portion of the future town of Steilacoom claimed by Capt. Lafayette Balch
The first incorporated town in what is now the state of Washington.
The largest river in the Pacific Northwest region of North America.
A tributary of the Puyallup River in Washington State

An archipelago in the Pacific Northwest of the United States between the U.S. state of Washington and Vancouver Island, British Columbia, Canada. The San Juan Islands are part of Washington state, and form the core of San Juan County.
The manifestation of a culture or sub-culture, especially in regard to the traditional and customary practices of a particular ethnic or other cultural groups.
An Indigenous tribe in what is now the state of Oregon in the United States.
An Indigenous people of the Great Plains.
Chinookan peoples include several groups of Indigenous people of the Pacific Northwest in the United States who speak the Chinookan languages.
An Indigenous people originally based in the Southeastern Woodlands, in what is now Alabama and Mississippi.

Muscogee Creek are a group of related indigenous peoples of the Southeastern Woodlands in the United States of America. Their original homelands are in what now comprises southern Tennessee, much of Alabama, western Georgia and parts of northern Florida.

An Indigenous tribe and First Nations band government in North America. They compose two of the three main subcultures of the Sioux people, and are typically divided into the Eastern Dakota and the Western Dakota.

A Lushootseed-speaking Indigenous tribe in western Washington, and the indigenous people of metropolitan Seattle, where they have been living since the end of the last glacial period (c. 8000 BCE, 10,000 years ago).
An indigenous group who have traditionally occupied Haida Gwaii, an archipelago just off the coast of British Columbia, Canada, for at least 12,500 years
An Indigenous people, part of the Seminole nation until the mid-20th century, when they organized as an independent tribe
An Indigenous people constituting a subdivision of the Lakota people, who formerly inhabited an area in western present-day South Dakota
An Indigenous people presumed to have lived on the Columbia River Plateau in the Pacific Northwest region for at least 11,500 years.
A Southern Coast Salish people.

Refers to three non-contiguous groups of indigenous peoples of the Great Basin. Although their languages are related within the Numic group of Uto-Aztecan languages, these three groups do not form a single set. The term "Paiute" does not refer to a single, unique, unified group of Great Basin tribes.
A Central Plains Indigenous tribe that historically lived in Nebraska and northern Kansas
A group of peoples who lived in what is now northern and eastern Scotland (north of the Firth of Forth) during Late Antiquity and the Early Middle Ages.
Coast Salish Indigenous tribe from western Washington state, United States.
An Indigenous Tribe of the Pacific Northwest of the US and SW Canada, identified by their use of the Salish languages which diversified out of Proto-Salish between 3,000 and 6,000 years ago
An Indigenous people who developed in Florida in the 18th century.
Groups of Indigenous tribes and First Nations peoples in North America.
A Lushootseed-speaking Indigenous people, located in present-day Washington in the United States. Also spelled Suquamish
A Coast Salish people of Washington state
A tribe of the Lushootseed people native to Puget Sound in Washington State
A Coast Salish people who lived in the Puget Sound area of Washington state in the United States.

The Stikine people are a ḵwáan or regional group of the Tlingit, indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast of North America. Their historical territory included Wrangell Island and other islands of the Alexander Archipelago, as well as the basin of the lower Stikine River.
In the extreme southwestern part of Puget Sound in Mason County, Washington, United States, the island is a reservation of the Native American Squaxin Island Tribe
A Sahaptin indigenous people of the Northwest Plateau.

Originally occupied the area on both sides of the Columbia River and on the northern branches of the Yakama (formerly Tapteal) and Wenatchee Rivers in the state of Washington. Originally spelled "Yakima," the Yakama nation renamed itself to "Yakama" in the mid-1990s to more closely reflect the proper pronunciation in their native tongue.
The state and condition of being a slave, someone forbidden to quit their service for an enslaver, and who is treated by the enslaver as their property.
A coming together of parties to a dispute, to present information (in the form of evidence) in a tribunal, a formal setting with the authority to adjudicate claims or disputes.
Trial of Nisqually War Chief Leschi for the "murder" of two militiamen in 1856
A series of print articles written by Lt. Kautz vigorously defending the innocence of Leschi

term.preferredTerm: A Historical Court of Inquiry and Justice
term.definition: Organization for retrial of Cheif Leschi in 2004 resulting in his exoneration.

The killing of the Washington missionaries Marcus Whitman and his wife Narcissa, along with eleven others, on November 29, 1847 by members of the Cayuse tribe who accused Whitman of having poisoned 200 Cayuse in his medical care; launched the Cayuse War.
Women responsible for the washing, ironing, and mending of clothing
A news article that reports the recent death of a prominent person.
The continually developing result of accumulated knowledge and application in all techniques, skills, methods, and processes used in industrial production and scientific research.
